columns.text: In this problem, we will tackle the concept of bonus depreciation and examine how it affects the net present value of a given project.

Bonus depreciation refers to the tax incentive that allows a huge portion of the amount of the asset to be subtracted from the pre-tax valuation of the cash flow. Since the problem states that there is a $100\%$ bonus depreciation on the first year, this means that the cash flow for the first year will be different compared to the previous question.

In the problem, it was stated that the earnings per year is projected at $\$155,000$. Since the asset qualifies for $100\%$ bonus depreciation in the first year, then the depreciation we will use for this year is $\$460,000$. 

Substituting the values, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Cash flow}&=\$155,000 \times (1-0.21)+\$460,000 \times 0.21\\[15 pt]
&=\$122,450 +\$96,600\\[15 pt]
&=\$219,050
\end{aligned}$$

The cash flow for year 1 is $\$219,050$
As already computed in the previous problem, the cash flow at Year 0 is $-\$489,000$ while the cash flow from Year 2 until Year 5 is $\$141,770$

We can then use this formula for the net present value to solve for the NPV of this project:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{NPV}&= \text{cash flow at Year 0} +\dfrac{\text{cash flow year 1}}{(1+\text{Required return})^1}\\
&+\dfrac{\text{cash flow year 2}}{(1+\text{Required return})^2}+\dfrac{\text{cash flow year 3}}{(1+\text{Required return})^3}\\
&+\dfrac{\text{cash flow year 4}}{(1+\text{Required return})^4}+\dfrac{\text{cash flow year 5}}{(1+\text{Required return})^5}\\
&+\dfrac{\text{Net working capital}+\text{After-tax salvage value}}{(1+\text{required return})^5}
\end{aligned}$$
